Title.evidence: METHODS:: A randomized controlled clinical trial was conducted

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomized controlled clinical trial was conducted at an orthopedic trauma surgery unit

Participants.evidence: The enrolled sample included 133 patients; 84 patients were randomized

Intervention.evidence: to compare a digital behavioral pain management intervention (“My Surgical Success” [MSS]) to a digital general health education (HE) intervention

Objective.evidence: This study tested a digital perioperative behavioral medicine intervention in orthopedic trauma surgery patients for feasibility and efficacy for reducing pain intensity, pain catastrophizing, and opioid cessation up to 3 months after surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Outcomes were collected at 1–3 months after intervention through self-report e-surveys and electronic medical record review

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: A randomized controlled clinical trial was conducted

Number_Randomised.evidence: 84 patients were randomized (MSS, n = 37; HE, n = 47)

Number_Analysed.evidence: 84 patients were randomized (MSS, n = 37; HE, n = 47) and completed study procedures

Result_Outcome.evidence: A significant interaction effect was found for treatment group over time on pain intensity, such that the MSS group evidenced greater absolute reductions in pain intensity after surgery and up to 3 months later (treatment × time fixed effects; F [215] = 5.23; P = .024)
